Subject: NEAT vs. GMDH / noisy time series

All,

I'm a research student at Humboldt University, Berlin, considering a =

couple of evolutionary neural network approaches to be used for 
creating =
models of noisy time series. Concerning NEAT, which seems 
very promising t=
o me, I do have the following questions:

How does NEAT compare (in estimat=
ing models from time series) to GMDH 
(group method of data handling: http:=
//www.gmdh.net) type neural 
networks ?
GMDH automatically selects relevant=
 inputs, evolves the topology 
(using genetic algorithms) and estimates coe=
fficients of polynomial 
transfer functions (using least squares for exampl=
e). Because of 
restricting the GA to the topology, the search space is kep=
t 
relatively small. Like in NEAT, networks are evolved from small to 
more=
 complex, in order find the least complex optimal solution. The 
gmdh metho=
d is supposed to be fast, working well on noisy, small 
sample data, insens=
itive to irrelevant inputs, and creates explicit 
models (algebraic equatio=
ns which can be analyzed).

Further questions are:
How well does NEAT perfo=
rm on noisy time series ? 

Does it require any enhancements to make NEAT m=
odel (noisy) time 
series well ?

Thank you for your help,
Achim
